{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3535961,"name":"Ryan zheng","username":"Rzheng1232","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/rzheng1232/{size}/182897_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-22T01:11:12.200Z","cooked":"

Hey guys,
I have a question about swerve drive. Recently after updating our Mk4i swerve code to the most recent libraries and wpilib version, I’ve noticed a strange behavior occurring where every time the robot code is deployed, the “drive straight forward” position angles are scrambled and the wheels end up getting offset by a bunch, forcing me to shut down the robot and realign the wheels. After debugging to isolate the issue, I think the issue seems to be when the wheels turn, the absolute encoder seems to track the position correctly, but the integrated motor encoders aren’t syncing correctly.
So, for example: The motor’s absolute encoder starts at an angle of 240 degrees, therefore the relative encoder starts at an angle at -40 degrees. This makes sense, since the relative encoder should be initialized as (absolute encoder value - the angle offset of 280 degrees), but the moment I start turning the wheel, difference between the absolute and integrated encoders rapidly increases to like 500 degrees or something.
Here is a link to my code: CrescendoCodeMigrated2025/CrescendoCodeUpdatedImported2025/src/main/java/frc/robot at main · DesteoyerRZSS/CrescendoCodeMigrated2025 · GitHub
Sorry if I didn’t explain it clearly enough, I’m still trying to figure it out myself.

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":5,"updated_at":"2025-02-22T01:11:12.200Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":22,"reads":54,"readers_count":53,"score":120.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":492661,"topic_slug":"swerve-module-integrated-and-absolute-encoders-for-angle-motors-arent-synchronized","display_username":"Ryan zheng","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://github.com/DesteoyerRZSS/CrescendoCodeMigrated2025/tree/main/CrescendoCodeUpdatedImported2025/src/main/java/frc/robot","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"CrescendoCodeMigrated2025/CrescendoCodeUpdatedImported2025/src/main/java/frc/robot at main · DesteoyerRZSS/CrescendoCodeMigrated2025 · GitHub","clicks":5}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":55168,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Programmer"},"post_url":"/t/swerve-module-integrated-and-absolute-encoders-for-angle-motors-arent-synchronized/492661/1","custom_user_title":"Programmer","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true,"can_vote":false},{"id":3536000,"name":"Justin Buist","username":"Justin_Buist","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/j/c77e96/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-02-22T01:43:51.272Z","cooked":"

I think I see what’s happening. If I’m right, fix is to go to SwerveModule.java, line 152, and wrap the integratedAngleEncoder.getPosition() call in your placeInAppropriate0To360Scope() from OnboardModuleState.java, or something similar.

Basically your absolute encoder is reporting 0-360. Your motor goes outside those ranges. if you make 2 rotations starting at 0 you’re at 720 degrees according to the motor. You have to put in the code to normalize it back down to 0-360. And that can mean negative numbers too! You can have a -720 degree rotation of the steering motors.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":5,"updated_at":"2025-02-22T01:43:51.272Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":43,"readers_count":42,"score":23.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":492661,"topic_slug":"swerve-module-integrated-and-absolute-encoders-for-angle-motors-arent-synchronized","display_username":"Justin Buist","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":24678,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/swerve-module-integrated-and-absolute-encoders-for-angle-motors-arent-synchronized/492661/2","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3536036,"name":"Ryan zheng","username":"Rzheng1232","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/rzheng1232/{size}/182897_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-22T02:33:10.653Z","cooked":"

Ok, I can see what you are talking about, and that’s something I should definitely fix. Mainly though, I find it strange that before deploying the robot, my integrated (relative) angle encoders are at 0 degrees (wheels facing straight forwards), but after deploying new code, the angle encoders are scrambled and are set to arbitrary values like 30 degrees, 100 degrees or what not. I can’t find any specific pattern in these values and it causes the wheels to become misaligned after redeploying the code.
Thanks!

Ahh, I see it. SwerveModule.java line 89. You’re setting your config on the CANCoders there and every module uses the same values.

With 0 for the magnet offset. So, you can either put the offset in the code (my preference) so it gets written to the device on every boot, or have your code skip setting the offset entirely and set the config via CTRE’s Tuner X.

Ok we ended up figuring it out. I’m not sure why, but in Swerve Module.java, resetToAbsolute method, instead of setting the integratedAngleEncoder position as the Absolute Position, I had to instead set it to 360-Absolute Position.
Thanks for your time and assistance though!
